Premier Burt announced on 20th of October announced that people should be further vigilant about maintaining physical distance, wearing masks and washing the hands.  Link: https://archive.fo/YIL98

Mask must be worn at anytime physical distance of 6 ft or 2 meters cannot be maintained from others. You do not need to wear a mask when at home, when exercising or if a child under the age of 2.  Mask Guidelines - http://web.archive.org/web/20201029004811/https://www.gov.bm/mask-guidance

When to wear a mask:  1. Workers at all workplace premises should wear masks - Frontline staff (e.g food handlers, cashiers), Those performing backend functions (e.g. data entry, payroll etc.),  2. If you leave the house to purchase essentials or for work: Wear a mask  3. While taking public transport or in taxis  4. At the grocery store  5. At anytime physical distance of 6 ft or 2 meteres cannot be maintained from others  You do not need to wear a mask when at home, when exercising or if a child under the age of 2.     Masks Guidance: http://web.archive.org/web/20201109222638/https://www.gov.bm/mask-guidance

Public schools across the country are broadly open for both elementary and high schools (although education is managed at the provincial level, meaning there are differing restrictions by province). However, many Canadian universities like York University and McGill are operating almost entirely online.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201020223057/https://www.mcgill.ca/coronavirus/case-status/mcgill-operational-status-coronavirus-information

Those students below the university level are broadly in school most days. Certain school boards are alternating online days for older students in hotspots like Quebec. Once again, most universities are operating online.     The province of Newfoundland and Labrador's only university, Memorial University, is operating online for example, meaning they have no in person university classes in the province. Although most universities are technically doing this of their own accord, almost every university in Canada is public and funded/deeply connected to their provincial governments. So, while many universities did this of their own accord, I've put T2 because of their strong links to the government, and preemptive action negated a need to pass laws. In short, there is no reason for certain provinces to pass legislation, because these shut downs have already been done, likely in consultation with the provincial governments. The fact stands that there are entire provinces which do not have in person learning at the university level. Hence T2.     The entire decision making process is happening at a very decentralized level, happening in individual universities within distinct provinces. It is not generally closed however, since certain universities are doing in person classes. One example of this is St Xavier University in Nova Scotia (a smaller liberal arts university).     Primary and Secondary School Links  https://web.archive.org/web/20201030192324/https://www.edu.gov.mb.ca/k12/covid/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201030191936/https://www.quebec.ca/en/education/organization-educational-activities-covid-19/  Closed University Links  https://web.archive.org/web/20201030192932/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201030194709/https://news.umanitoba.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Your-Safety-is-Our-Priority-resUMe-2020.pdf  Open University Links  https://web.archive.org/web/20201030194314/https://www.stfx.ca/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20201030194511/https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2020/09/07/despite-covid-19-these-universities-will-hold-in-person-classes-heres-how-theyre-preparing-for-the-risk.html
School policy is still dictated by provinces, and thus varies, but using the example of universities in Newfoundland, there are no in person classes, qualifying it as 2T.

In re-emerging hotspots like Toronto, lots of different business sectors have been shut down, including, casinos, cinemas, interactive exhibits, performing arts centres, gambling establishments, indoor gyms, yoga/dance studios.   "The orders, which come into effect at 12:01 a.m. on October 10 and will be in place for at least 28 days include:"  https://web.archive.org/web/20201020213512/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-what-you-should-do/covid-19-orders-directives-by-laws/

Quebec has extended its measures once again, until November 23rd. This means indoor dining/gyms will remain closed in hotspots.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201029021256/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/legault-restrictions-grade-9-red-zones-1.5777395

Highly territorial, but Winnipeg recently closed certain sectors like Casinos and recreational facilities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200337/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/winnipeg/index.html#wmr_restrictions

Limitations vary by jurisdiction, but are cancelled in many places. In sections of Quebec at level 4 alert for example, public events are prohibited. Restrictions vary by province, but certain places, like "red areas" in Quebec continue ban public events  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109204328/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/progressive-regional-alert-and-intervention-system/level-4-maximum-alert-red/

Limitations vary by jurisdiction. In sections of Quebec at level 4 alert for example, gatherings are prohibited. Quebec has extended its measures once again, until November 23rd. This means limitations on gatherings continue, with especially harsh ones (only within the family bubble) in hotspots    https://web.archive.org/web/20201029021256/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/legault-restrictions-grade-9-red-zones-1.5777395

Restrictions vary by province, but certain places, like "orange areas" in Quebec continue to cap gatherings at 6.  Winnipeg has recently lowered their gathering size to 5 to counteract the spike.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200337/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/winnipeg/index.html#wmr_restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200035/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/progressive-regional-alert-and-intervention-system/level-3-alert-orange/
Transit rules and levels have not changed since last updated

Although there are requirements for mask wearing for transit in places like Vancouver, it does not seem like public transit is being shut down.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201029021024/https://new.translink.ca/rider-guide/coronavirus-precautions
Public transit remains open.
No change or forced stay at home requirements added.
People are still generally recommended to stay home. The premier of Quebec in particular has urged people, although it does not seem to qualify as a requirement as of yet.
The federal government continues to advise people to stay at home.

Many places have quarantine measures in effect upon arrival, and much of Eastern Canada is not allowing anybody from outside the region in at all. Newfoundland and Labrador is below as an example.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201020214712/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/travel-restrictions/

Many provinces and territories have two week quarantine requirements, including Manitoba and Nunavut for example. Interestingly, those who go to a province like Manitoba must isolate upon arrival. However, going up to Nunavut, people isolate at a hotel first for two weeks, then travel to Nunavut (it should be noted that A: Nunavut is a territory and thus predominantly under federal jurisdiction- certainly far more than a province might be and B: Nunavut has a very small spread out population without the resources to isolate people easily). Eastern provinces continue with the most extreme version of internal restriction of movement, again with Newfoundland in particular banning all those from outside the East.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201029020109/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/protection/soe.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201029015514/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/travel-restrictions/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201029020125/https://www.macleans.ca/society/health/how-nunavut-has-stayed-coronavirus-free-as-a-second-wave-hits-canada/

Travel and quarantine restrictions are varied by province, the most extreme of which continues to be the outright ban for those outside the maritimes to enter Newfoundland.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201109204109/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/travel-restrictions/

Extremely restrictive rules. Only allowing in residents, those with family members who are Canadian, some temporary workers, transiting passengers, and essential US workers (like truck drivers). Tourists are not allowed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201020214350/https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/coronavirus-covid19/travel-restrictions-exemptions.html#other
No change found in travel controls.
No change.

Wage subsidy system continues. It has been extended in its current from until December, and will continue in some form into June, as per the recent Speech from the Throne (significant speech made by the Prime Minister). The wage scheme is relatively complicated, but in almost all normal scenarios the government is providing more than 50% of lost income.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201020221351/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/10/extending-the-canada-emergency-wage-subsidy.html
Programs continue on as usual, with the next seemingly important date for revision coming in December.
As noted before, policy was extended. No change.

Many of these broad actions are happening, but not at a federal level. In most places hydro (electricity) and water disconnections are postponed, but this is often determined on a municipal or provincial level.  Furthermore, while some places, like Vancouver and Toronto have ended their eviction freezes, almost everywhere had an eviction freeze at one point. Same with student loan freezes as well. This is something to dig into once researchers begin categorizing subnational Canadian data, because almost all of Canada would classify as 2 at the beginning of the pandemic, and certain places would continue until present. That being said, because the response is so decentralized, the Canadian Federal response can continue to be categorized as 1.
I'd repeat my note from October 16th, stating that much of this is happening at the provincial level, so it is not getting accounted for in federal assessments.
As noted before, policy was extended. No change in debt relief
Public campaign continues
Campaign continues. Some provinces have ramped up as well, as waves begin to hit places like Manitoba again, which haven't had significant case numbers in several months
Tests are generally available
Contract tracing program continues.       https://web.archive.org/web/20201020212020/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html
Tracing is broad

At the provincial level, places like New Brunswick and Ontario have mandatory masking in all public indoor spaces   https://web.archive.org/web/20201020220452/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/dam/gnb/Departments/eco-bce/Promo/covid-19/MandatoryMasksFAQ.pdf
Masks are still mandatory in public spaces within certain provinces. New Brunswick is one which has particularly strong

While many places like Toronto, Quebec, and Manitoba are requiring masks at all indoor spaces, however certain places in New Brunswick, like Moncton, have gone further, requiring it in all public spaces. Outdoor single family yards are exempt  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109205125/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/moncton-campbellton-masks-mandatory-outside-1.5759496  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200337/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/winnipeg/index.html#wmr_restrictions

According to the latest data from Edweek's tracker, some US states (inducing Hawaii, California, and West Virginia) mandate school closures in some parts of their states due to the risk of infection. Some US territories (Washington DC, Puerto Rico) continue with full closures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108171154/https://www.edweek.org/ew/section/multimedia/map-covid-19-schools-open-closed.html?cmp=eml-enl-eu-mostpop&M=59726363&U=&UUID=96155749d7cc9a7eb4e153ce431f8907

NYT tracker shows substantial reopening since last note. Nevertheless, some businesses, particularly bars, remain closed in certain states (ex: TX, CA, NM)  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108172558/https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/states-reopen-map-coronavirus.html

Some jurisdictions (e.g. some areas of California) require events to be cancelled if criteria on cases are not met. Most states require events to proceed with distancing and other sanitary precautions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108172808/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases

Hawaii appears to have the strictest gathering limits in the nation, with gatherings of over 10 people not permitted. Some other states, like Connecticut, limit gatherings of over 25.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108172834/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html
Public transit systems throughout the country are open but often operate with restrictions.
No state currently enforces a stay-at-home order, but some continue to recommend doing so.
States like New York require visitors from non-contiguous states to quarantine upon arrival.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108173014/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory
The United States continues to prevent arrivals from certain countries. https://web.archive.org/web/20201108173016/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
Funds continue to be available for some programmes.
Evictions relief continues until 1 January.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108190335/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-eviction-declaration.html
CDC information campaign continues.
In some states (such as Arizona), testing is generally available.
No policy change noted.

In several states, facial coverings are required whenever distancing is impossible (NC, OH, and many others). In Nevada, mask-wearing is always required outside the home.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108190507/https://www.aarp.org/health/healthy-living/info-2020/states-mask-mandates-coronavirus.html#Nevada
